metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value: 200,000 living  In metropolitan  Charleston  A population of 200,000 persons, or  possiby more, is estimated for the  Charleston metropolitan area, including the area between the Ashley and Cooper rivers but excuding the areas least of the Cooper  and west of the Ashley rivers, according to a report just sent to  Washington by the Charleston post-office.  The report is based on issuance  of rationing books, canceations of  etters, postoffice receipts, money  orders handed and other data gathered by the postoffice.  with an estimated 200,000 persons  on the "neck", Charleston county"s  population may be estimated conservativey at 225,000. The 1940  t census gave the rura population  of the county as 15,968 and since  that time hundreds of new homes  have been buit in suburban developments in St. Andrew"s parish  and James Island and the population of Foy Island, Mount pleasant  and Suivan"s Island has grown tremendousy. Though no official figures are obtainable on the miitary  population of the Charleston area,  it will tota we over 10,000 persons.  Posta receipts for the first five  months of 1943 totaed $265,554.34,  compared to $215,471.77 for the same  period last year, according to figures reeased yesterday by Postmaster Phiip M. Cement.  Canceations of mail for May totaed 2,147,128, compared to 1,519.325  for May, 1942. special deivery mail  increased from 14,632 to 17,006.  Money order business handed during May totaed $652,048.49, compared to $483,573.40 for May, 1942,  according to Henry H. Cochran, assistant postmaster.  Bank cearings for the first five  months of 1943 totaed $48,212,642.63,  compared to $41,339,300.46 for the  same period of 1942, according to  the Charleston Cearing House associaltion. The tota of clearances last  month was $9,751,331.23, compared  to $8,272,921.49 for May, 1942.  The tota number of War Ration  Book I issued by the Charleston  county rationing board was estimated last week at 200,000. Census  figures for 1940 gave tire county a  population of 121,105 persons.  Marriage icenses issued last  month by Carence F. unz, judge  of probate, totaed 269, of which 186  were to white coupes and eighty-  three to negroes. It was the largest  number of white icenses issued in  one month so far this year. -  The News and Courier and the  Charleston Evening Post report a  76 per cent increase in combined  daiy circuation in the metropolitan  Charleston area since 1940.  The Housing Authority of the City  of Charleston has under construction 1,286 housing units in the area  north of the city, and bids will be  opened in a few days for 750 Additional units to be rented to negroes.  The Federal government"s home  use conversion program expects to  have 150 units ready for occuplancy  in about sixty days, and 3,000 units  are under construction or in contempation by private construction  agencies.  The V Housing corporation, which  is in the midst of a program of constructing 2,500 housing units, has  1.000 of these under construction in  the area north of the city. Work is  expected to begin in the city on  construction of 115 units, and within six to eight weeks on about 400  units in Byrnes Down, a new subdivision to be opened in St. Andrew"s parish.  The South Carolina Power complany reported that its buses in the  first four months of 1943 haued 11,251,764 passengers, compared to 5,891,930 in the same period of 1942.  Figures for May were not avaiable  last night, but it is expected they  will be greaty in excess of Aprii.  The Charleston navy yard continues to expland, according to reports of Additional construction authorizations received daiy from  Washington.  The Pittsburgh Metaurgica complany"s plant also is being enlarged  constanty. Contempated in the  near future is a llarge aumina plant  near Hoy Hi and it is reasonable  to suppose that many of its empoyes will ive in the Charleston  trading  area.
